title: PCT 22: An embassy to the Snakes
author: Simon Mimikwas

sentences.english: There were six of us who set out.

sentences.original: wiyâpahtamâhkoh mîkiwâhpah, nikâsôwanân, êkâ ta-wâpamikoyâhkok ayahciyiniwak,
sentences.text: wiyâpahtamâhko mîkiwâhpa nikâsowânân êkâ ta-wâpamikoyâhkok ayahciyiniwak
sentences.english: When we saw any tipis, we hid from the people, lest the Blackfoot see us.

sentences.original: êh-pimohtatâyâhk ôtêh ohci ayôwinisah, êh-ntawih-wîtaskiyâhk wâhyaw awasâpisk.
sentences.text: ê-pimohtatâyâhk ôtê ohci ayiwinisa ê-nitawi-wîtaskiyâhk wâhyaw awasâpisk
sentences.english: We were carrying garments with us, from here, for we were bound on an embassy far beyond the Rocky Mountains.

sentences.original: piyisk nôtihtênân asinîwaciy, têpiskâki pikoh êh-pimohtêyâhk, êkâ awiyak ta-nôtinikoyâhk, ê-wîh-kakwê-takohtêyâhk itêh k-êtohtêyâhk.
sentences.text: piyisk nôtihtênân asinîwaciy têpiskâki piko ê-pimohtêyâhk êkâ awiyak ta-nôtinikoyâhk ê-wî-kakwê-takohtêyâhk itê kâ-itohtêyâhk
sentences.english: At last we came to the Rocky Mountains, walking the while only at night, lest anyone fight with us, for we meant to reach our destination.
At last we arrived beyond the Rockies.

sentences.original: êkotê piyisk mînisah miywâsinwah, iyikonk êh-takohtêyâhk.
sentences.text: êkotê piyisk mînisa miywâsinwa iyikohk ê-takohtêyâhk
sentences.english: The berries were ripe by the time we arrived.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-wâpahtamâhk mîkiwâhpah, namoya nikîh-pîhtokânân, osâm êkâ ê-kîh-nipâcik oskinîkiwak, êkâ ta-wâpamikoyâhkok.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-wâpahtamâhk mîkiwâhpa namôya nikî-pîhtokânân osâm êkâ ê-kî-nipâcik oskinîkiwak êkâ ta-wâpamikoyâhkok
sentences.english: When we came in sight of the tipis, we did not enter, for we did not care to have them see us before the young warriors were asleep.
For quite a while we stayed in hiding.

sentences.original: êkosi kîtahtawê êkwah nkaskihtânân pîhtiyisk êh-cimatêk mîkiwâhp, êh-okimâwit kinêpikoyiniw.
sentences.text: êkosi kîtahtawê êkwa nikaskihtânân pîhtêyask ê-cimatêk mîkiwâhp ê-okimâwit kinêpikoyiniw
sentences.english: Then in time we managed to gain the tipi which stood in the center, that of the Snake who was chief.
We entered when it was dark.
When we entered, the chief arose from his couch.
So they made only a small fire.
With his wives, they were only three, for he had two wives.

sentences.original: êkosi pêyak wayawîw awa, êh-atotak, niwîcêwâkan;
sentences.text: êkosi pêyak wayawîw awa ê-atotak niwîcêwâkan
sentences.english: So then I bade one of my companions go out;
he took the things;

sentences.original: kahkiyaw pîhtokatâw ayôwinisah ôhi êh-pimohtatâyâhk, êh-nitawih-mêkiyâhk, mîna nanâtohk akohpah.
sentences.text: kahkiyaw pîhtokatâw ayiwinisa ôhi ê-pimohtatâyâhk ê-nitawi-mêkiyâhk mîna nanâtohk akohpa
sentences.english: he brought in all the things we carried with us to give away, and all kinds of blanket-robes.
Then they were set down before him whose tent we had entered.
Then he spoke to his wives; they went out.
Presently his wives came in.
At times his father came in.
So then he spoke to his father; the latter would go out.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-pîhtokêyit ôhtâwiya, wah-wayawîwak ôki iskwêwak, kotakihk êh-tohtêcik.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-pîhtokêyit ôhtâwiya wa-wayawîwak ôki iskwêwak kotakihk ê-itohtêcik
sentences.english: In this fashion, when his father came in, his wives would go out, and go to some other place.
Then other chiefs began to come in.
The tent became crowded.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah awa okimâw pîkiskwêw : hâw, êh-âtah-sâkwêyimoyân, kikîh-miyinâwâw t-ôkimâwiyân.
sentences.english: Then that chieftain spoke: “Now then, although I was unwilling, you made me chief.

sentences.original: êkosi kintawêyimitinâwâw êkâ ta-pâsitahkoskêyêk ôma kâ-wîh-ititakok.
sentences.english: Accordingly, I now ask of you not to overstep that which I shall tell you.

sentences.original: kîspin kîh-pêh-macih-nôcihtâcik, kitêmiwâwak tahtoh kâ-miyosicik kah-kimotamâkawinâwâw; êkosi mîna niyah nkah-nipahikok.
sentences.english: Had they come here with evil designs, you would have been robbed of as many of your horses as are handsome; and likewise, me they would have killed.
Without my knowledge, and while I was yet asleep, they made a fire.
Then they awakened me.

sentences.original: êk ohci ôhi k-âstêkih êh-pêh-ntawih-miyicik ayôwinisah, mîna môsw-asiniyah, mîna kaskitêw.
sentences.english: Their purpose was to come give me these things that lie here, garments, and bullets, and powder.
Accordingly, I ask of you that you be good friends.
Tomorrow I shall call upon you to come here and make friends with them.
There, this is what I had to say to you,” he said to his followers;
“It was for this that I summoned you.”

sentences.original: hâw, omah k-êtwêyin namoya nka-kî-miyâskênân kipîkiskwêwin, itik ôhi otôskinîkiyima.
sentences.english: “Now, this which you have spoken we shall not by any chance transgress, this speech of yours,” his followers answered him.
“But now, what sort of men are they?”
Thereupon the chief asked them.

sentences.original: wîhtamawêw pêyak awa nâpêw, êwako ciwayân k-êtiht : nêhiyawak niyanân, itêw;
sentences.text: wîhtamawêw pêyak awa nâpêw êwako ciwayân kâ-itiht itêw
sentences.english: One of those men, the one whose name was Tehiwayan, told him: “We are Cree,” he told him;
“And we have come with the express purpose of visiting you.

sentences.original: êh-itêyihtamâhk, êwakô ohci ôtah kâ-wâpamiyâhk, itêw.
sentences.english: 'We shall see much of the earth,' was our thought, and therefore you see us here,” he told him.
Then those chieftains went home to bed.
Only then did he address his father.
Thereupon the latter went out.

sentences.original: ê-kîh-kîwêyit ôhtâwiya awa okimâw, êkwêyêk êkwah pîhtwâwak.
sentences.text: ê-kî-kîwêyit ôhtâwiya awa okimâw êkwêyâk êkwa pîhtwâwak
sentences.english: When the chief's father had gone home, only then did they smoke.

sentences.original: êkosi pîhtokêyiwa wîwah awah okimâw, êh-pêtâyit ta-mîcisocik ôki kâ-ntawih-wîtaskîcik.
sentences.text: êkosi pîhtokêyiwa wîwa awa okimâw ê-pêtâyit ta-mîcisocik ôki kâ-nitawi-wîtaskîcik
sentences.english: Then the chief's wives came in, bringing food for those to eat who had come to make a treaty.
When they had eaten they left the tipi;
the chief went with them.

sentences.original: sipwêhtêwak; nâtêwak otêmiwâwa mînah kotakah ayôwinisah.
sentences.text: sipwêhtêwak nâtêwak otêmiwâwa mîna kotaka ayiwinisa
sentences.english: They went from there; they fetched their horses and their other things.
Then, when they came back, they tethered their horses.

sentences.original: êkos îsi pâh-pîhtokatâwak ôki iskwêwak ôhi nêhiyawa kêkway êh-pêh-miyikocik.
sentences.text: êkosi isi pâh-pîhtokatâwak ôki iskwêwak ôhi nêhiyawa kêkway ê-pê-miyikocik
sentences.english: Then those women began to bring into their dwelling the things which the Cree had given them when they came.

sentences.original: êkos îsi pîhtokêwak kahkiyaw ôki nâpêwak.
sentences.text: êkosi isi pîhtokêwak kahkiyaw ôki nâpêwak
sentences.english: Then all those men went into the tent.
So then they went to bed.
When day broke, they got up.
They were well cared for.
When they had eaten, the women put the dwelling in order.
Then they went out;
the chief's father entered.
He told him of the arrival of other chiefs who had been summoned by calling.
When all were there, they entirely filled that tent.
Presently one more chief was sent for.
He arrived.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah wîh-nipahêw êwakô ncawâc awa okimâw.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa wî-nipahêw êwako nicawâc awa okimâw
sentences.english: Then this chief thought it best to kill them.
“Now then, my brother in arms, you will kill me too.
If you are to kill them, you will kill me too.”
Then a woman was called who spoke Cree.
She came there; she came into the tent.
Then that one Cree was questioned.

sentences.original: âh, namôya! namôya êh-pêh-nipahtâkêyân, mînah namoya êh-nôhtê-kimotoyân.
sentences.english: “Oh, no! It was not for murder that I came here, and not because I wanted to steal.
'Suppose I go and smoke; suppose I go and eat,' was what I had in mind,” said that Cree.
Then that chief was told this.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah ôkwêmêsah misatimwah nîso miyêw êh-mihkawikiyit, kiyâm êkâh ta-pisiskêyimâyit ôhi kâ-nôhtên-nipahâyit.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa okwêmêsa misatimwa nîso miyêw ê-mîhkawikiyit kiyâm êkâ ta-pisiskêyimâyit ôhi kâ-nôhtê-nipahâyit
sentences.english: Thereupon he gave his friend two swift horses, that he might cease to mind those whom he desired to kill.
He consented.

sentences.original: êkos îsi miyêw cistêmâwa, môsasiniyah, kaskitêw, mîna ayôwinisah.
sentences.text: êkosi isi miyêw cistêmâwa môsasiniya kaskitêw mîna ayiwinisa
sentences.english: Then likewise he gave him tobacco, bullets, powder, and garments.
Thereupon they went home.
Those Cree stayed there all winter.
They were given very many horses.
Then, when summer came, they made ready to depart.
The Snake who was the Cree leader's friend accompanied him a ways.

sentences.original: iyikohk wâhyaw êh-pêy-âyâcik, êkoyikohk kîwêyiwa okwêmêsah.
sentences.text: iyikohk wâhyaw ê-pê-ayâcik êkoyikohk kîwêyiwa okwêmêsa
sentences.english: When they had gone quite a ways on the hither journey, only then did his friend go back.
The others had given them fifty-six horses.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah, wâpamacih ayahciyiniw, wîh-nipahiskih, wêpinâhkanik ôki misatimwak kâ-mîkawiyêk.
sentences.english: And so then, “If you see Blackfoot and they want to kill you, give rein to these horses that have been given to you.
They are very swift.
Simply flee for home.
In this way you will easily reach your country.”
So then they went home.

sentences.original: êkosi têpiskâki iyikohk, pimohtêw, êkâ ta-wâpamikot ayahciyiniwa.
sentences.text: êkosi têpiskâki iyikohk pimohtêw êkâ ta-wâpamikot ayahciyiniwa
sentences.english: Then only at night did he march, so as not to be seen by the Blackfoot.
At last he had passed them.
When it was almost winter, he arrived.
One Blackfoot had stolen horses from them, and him they overtook.
They took them away from him.
Then, when he tried to kill them, they killed him.
So they went home.

sentences.original: êkotah ohci kâ-kîh-ihtakohk kiyôtêwin wîtaskîwin, êkâ ta-kimotamâtocik têmiwâwa.
sentences.text: êkota ohci kâ-kî-ihtakohk kiyôtêwin wîtaskîwin êkâ ta-kimotamâtocik otêmiwâwa
sentences.english: So began the mutual visiting and the alliance and the agreement not to steal each other's horses.

sentences.original: êkoyikohk pêyak pipon, iyikohk êsa ê-kih-sipwêhtêt, pîtos-iyiniwa otaskiyihk ê-kîh-ayât.
sentences.text: êkoyikohk pêyak pipon iyikohk êsa ê-kî-sipwêhtêt pîtos-iyiniwa otaskiyihk ê-kî-ayât
sentences.english: It was one year from the time when he had set out on his visit to the foreigners' country.

sentences.original: tâpwê nisâkihikok kinêpikoyiniwak, kîh-itwêw êwako kisêyiniw :
sentences.english: “Truly, the Snake people were fond of me,” said that old man;
“'Would they might never deal wrongly with each other, when they see one another,' I used to say, when I was chief.

sentences.original: êyakô ohci nanâtohk ayîsiyiniwak k-ô-kîh-sâkihicik : namoya wîhkâc n-ôh-nipahtâkân.
sentences.english: That is why all kinds of people loved me: I never killed people.
All the time I was in the Blackfoots' country.

sentences.original: êkosi kiyîwêyâni ntaskîhk isi, nkîh-mâna-pîkiskâtâwak ayahciyiniwak.
sentences.english: And when I went home, they would always regret my departure, the Blackfoot.
Because I was of decent and righteous character, is why I reached old age.
'That is the way you must try to be, my children, even thus.
You must deal rightly with every human being,' I always told my children.”
There, that is all.
There, even so.
